events.text: As far as the eye could see, fires blazed as bright as the sun. The air was seasoned with the tang of gunpowder.
With every step he walked, another building, another person, another nuisance fell, and Hiroshi knew that the path to a beautiful future was being paved.
Hurried footsteps came from behind, and, tightening his grip on his rifle, he whipped around.
It was one of his soldiers, looking winded and tripping over his own feet in his hurry.
Speak!
Unable to regain his breath, the soldier pointed behind him and gestured frantically.
Not bothering to wait for an explanation, Hiroshi shoved past the soldier and ran off in the indicated direction.
Cries of anguish transformed into cries of battle, the further he ran.
Eventually, past all the rubble and smoke, the roof of a buddhist monastery rose into sight, standing tall and untouched.
Hiroshi arrived at the top of the hill to the monastery, but he was thrown onto the ground when one of his soldiers flew right into him!
With a grunt, he rolled out from under them, but he had barely gotten to his feet when a strong gust of wind sent him tumbling back to the ground.
ARGHH!! What’s going on?!
He dug his fingers into the rough dirt, crawling forward even though the wind made his eyes water and blur his vision.
In a brief moment of stillness, Hiroshi saw five monks standing in front of the temple facing his men, who were scattered onto the ground like he was.
Nearly all of them were bleeding profusely and lifeless, but another look at the monks told him they didn’t carry any lethal weapons.
In fact, they had not a single weapon, although the one in the middle was holding an awfully large leaf?
[i]BANG[/i]
To his left, Hiroshi saw the last of his soldiers here shooting with desperation.
The monks did not flinch whatsoever, but the one with the leaf swung it, creating another impossibly strong gust of wind.
Hiroshi ducked his head and was barely able to see the blood spurt from the soldier where his bullet was returned to him.
Commander, what should we do?
It was the soldier who had crashed into Hiroshi earlier. Turns out he hadn’t died yet, surprisingly.
Gather reinforcements! Hurry!
As the soldier scrambled off to call for help, Hiroshi turned back to find all the monks watching him.
Cursing mentally, Hiroshi got to his feet, gripping his rifle tightly as he stepped forward.
The monks exchanged glances, then the one with the leaf fan retreated inside.
Soon after, a faint golden light seeped out of the monastery.
Hiroshi would’ve gladly liked to know the cause, but the other four monks were quickly encroaching upon him.
For people who value peace, they were surprisingly skilled at hand to hand combat, redirecting each and every one of Hiroshi’s attempts to shoot them.
Not to mention that they outnumbered him.
Ugh!
He stumbled backwards breathlessly after a monk delivered a blow to his diaphragm.
He mentally prepared himself for another blow, but it never came because the monks retreated backwards, and the sound of many heavy footsteps told him why.
Reinforcements pushed the monks back steadily, and in this moment, Hiroshi could see that the light coming from the monastery was more intense than before.
He jumped to his feet and dashed towards the monastery, sensing that something was amiss.
The monks made to stop him, but the reinforcements kept them busy.
At the center of the monastery, Hiroshi found the monk from earlier, standing behind the leaf fan, which was suspended in mid-air, and muttering rapidly.
Light emitted from said fan, and an array that had appeared on the floor.
Suddenly, wind blew violently from below and the light from the array shone even more intensely.
Without another thought, Hiroshi raised his rifle and took aim. In the moment he pulled the trigger the light and wind ceased, and in the next, so did the monk.
Seeing that the monk was dead, he ran forward and picked up the leaf fan that had now fallen to the floor.
He couldn’t help the smile that came to his face upon feeling the weight of it in his hand.
Commander! We’ve restrained the monks!
Good. Bring them in so I can give them a taste of their own medicine.
However, as Hiroshi waited for the monks to be brought into the monastery, a fresh burning smell prompted him to turn around.
What greeted him was the sight of flames crawling up from where he had killed the monk, eating away shelves of books and scrolls along the walls.
In desperation, Hiroshi swung the leaf fan, but there was no wind. Not even a slight breeze.
Confused, he swung it again. And again. And again.
Frantically, he waved it back and forth rapidly, but the fan showed no signs of its former prowess.
What did you do? What did you [i]do[/i]?!
Hiroshi ran towards the deceased monk, as if he would get answers, eyes darting around the monastery for an explanation.
Then, on a table behind the monk, he glimpsed a drawing of the fan gracing the pages of a burning manuscript.
Without hesitation, he reached for it, throwing it onto the floor and stomping out the fire.
The manuscript was still hot when he picked it up, but he didn’t care. He needed to know what the monk had done to the fan.
His eyes scanned what little was left as he exited the monastery, passing his soldiers and the captured monks.
[i]Ancient artifact…Beyuls…Sun Wukong…[/i]
Nothing he could make sense of.
He cried out in anger, whipping out his rifle and killing one of the monks in a blind fit.
KILL THEM!! KILL THEM ALL!!
The subsequent sounds of gunfire told him his commands were followed.
Since that day almost a year ago, Hiroshi had flipped through the half-burnt manuscript countless times. And each time, he could not decipher anything new.
Most of the words had been burnt away, but some fragments of drawings, much like the drawing of the fan, had remained.
There must be more.
He had seen the power the fan held. He had seen the potential. And he would have it. For Japan. For a better future.
Now, Hiroshi was sitting in an empty restaurant, waiting for food… and news.
The shopkeeper came over with a steaming bowl of ramen and set it in front of him, bowing slightly before hurrying away.
Hearing the door to the restaurant bang open, Hiroshi stowed the manuscript and leaf fan away in his coat, sitting up as his subordinate approached.
Commander, I have news.
Speak.
There is this group of westerners we discovered in Hawaii, and have just received news that they have arrived in Tokyo.
... And?
One of these westerners is … Professor Howard Allwright.
Hiroshi’s eyebrows shot up. Ever since that incident, he had tried to find anyone who had done research on mystical Buddhist myths, including the one about beyuls.
However, there were only a few people in the world who seemed to have any knowledge about it, and they included Howard Allwright of UCLA and Rajesh Ghoshal of the University of Calcutta.
Hiroshi had kept tabs on their research, but after a while, considered them a dead end.
He’s here?
According to our intel, they are heading to the Himilyayas, and appear to be looking for… [i]beyuls[/i]. They also seem to have an artifact with them, an artifact similar to your own.
Keep an eye on them. And, if you notice their artifact has any mystical properties, I want them arrested and handed to me as soon as possible. Got that?
The spy saluted.
Yes, sir.
The spy turned around and left.
As soon as the spy left, Hiroshi relaxed and abruptly burst into laughter.
Hahaha! Finally! God himself has delivered a golden opportunity onto my lap! Soon, I will finally unlock the secrets of this damn fan.
Japan will finally be able to integrate all of Asia into the Empire, and NO ONE will be able to stop us.
Hiroshi, with a satisfied smile, broke apart his wooden chopsticks and began eating.
